Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Dual Source Single Crystal X-ray Diffractometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Programs. Professor Carla Slebodnick from Virginia Polytechnic Institute & State University and colleagues David Kingston, Victoria Soghomonian, Nancy Ross, and Bin Xu are acquiring an X-ray diffractometer with a dual molybdenum and copper source. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles. The instrument provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of undergraduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution, as well as collaborators from regional institutions. Training in specialized methods such as high pressure and biomolecular crystallography prepare students for challenges in both academia and industry. This instrument serves as a regional facility with students and faculty from many neighboring colleges accessing and collaborating on research projects.

The diffractometer enhances research and education at all levels. It especially aids in investigating perovskites and related mineral-inspired substances, metal-organic-frameworks (commonly referred to as MOFs), and electronic materials. The diffractometer is also used in small molecule determinations that may be relevant to the drug discovery. The instrument is essential for studies requiring biomacromolecular crystallography.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The dual-source Synergy single-crystal X-ray diffractometer (Fig. 1) acquired with NSF MRI grant 1726077 forms the nucleus of the Virginia Tech Crystallography Laboratory (VTX) which is an educational, research, and service center for the Virginia Tech campus and across the Commonwealth of Virginia. A broad range of VT undergraduate, graduate, and faculty research programs rely on Synergy which provides 3-dimensional structural information from diffraction of single-crystals (Fig. 2, Fig. 3). High-pressure studies, combined with the capabilities of Synergy allows VT students and faculty to discover new materials critical to the nation?s current and future needs in energy sciences and sustainability as well as health and biomedical research.

The outcomes enabled by the acquisition of Synergy cover cover two broad areas of research. Area 1 (functional materials) includes a diverse range of materials of interest for gas storage and carbon capture, geochemistry, glass and ceramic industries, membrane technology, optical and electrical material including, solar cell photovoltaics.  Area 2 (small molecule drug discovery) provides structural information for small molecules showing promise in the global fight against malaria and central nervous system diseases, the development of antimicrobial agents, and sustainable synthesis (green-chemistry).  

The research enabled by Synergy has broad impact ranging from electronic devices to new medicines in partnership with Virginia Tech?s Drug Discovery Center and VT?s initiative in Economical and Sustainable Materials.  VTX nationally contributes to the Materials Genome Initiative. VTX is committed to diversity and education through courses and hands-on experiential learning.  Undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, and faculty members are trained in crystallography methods, contributing to 7 graduate student dissertations to date. The VTX training facilitates the use of national neutron and synchrotron laboratories, and ensures the continued presence of a highly skilled workforce in this area.  The impact of VTX also extends well beyond VT, serving as a regional facility for undergraduate institutions and industries as well as  international collaborations.
